STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 17, 2020
Michelle Carlton
Child Safe Michigan Judson CS
4410 West 13 Mile Road
Royal Oak, MI 48073
RE: License #: CB630369213
Child Safe Michigan Judson CS
4410 West 13 Mile Road
Royal Oak, MI 48073
Dear Ms. Carlton:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on July 13, 15,
16, 28, 29, 30, 2020 and August 3, 4, 5, 10, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified Implementation, Sustainability and
Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations, explain why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Alicia Wiggins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 917-1048
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Name: Judson CS
Licensee Address: 30301 Northwestern HWY

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record shall contain all of the following
information before employment may occur:
(f) If the employee has criminal convictions, the chief
administrator or his or her designee shall complete a written
evaluation of the convictions that addresses the nature of the
conviction, the length of time since the conviction, and the
relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
Ten out of thirteen employee records reviewed were newly hired employees. In one
out of the ten newly hired employee records reviewed, there was no documentation
that the chief administrator or his or her designee completed a written evaluation of
the employee’s conviction that addresses the nature of the conviction, the length of
time since the conviction, and the relationship of the conviction to regulated activity.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED —2018 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 10, 2018.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
In one out of six foster children records reviewed the foster child’s initial medical
exam was not completed within 30 calendar days after the placement. The foster
child entered care on April 26, 2019 and the initial medical exam was completed on
July 12, 2019.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
4

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
(2)(a) In one out of six foster children records reviewed, which required an initial
service plan (ISP), the service plan was not completed within 30 calendar days from
removal from the home. The ISP was due on May 25, 2019 and it was completed on
May 30, 2019.
(2)(b) In one out of six foster children records reviewed, an updated service plan (USP)
was not completed at least once every 90 calendar days. The USP was due on June
9, 2019 and it was completed on June 11, 2019.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (2)(b)—2018 Interim Inspection, CAP
approved September 10, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for (2)(a) and (2)(b)—2019 Renewal
Inspection, CAP approved June 11, 2019.
R 400.12604 Orientation and application.
(1) An agency shall provide an orientation for prospective
applicants for adoption before an adoptive application is
provided. The orientation shall include a review of all of the
following:
(a) Program statement, policies, and procedures.
(b) Needs and characteristics of children available for
adoption.
(c) Services and resources available.
(d) Fees and charges.
(e) Legal process.
(f) Training requirements.
(g) Post adoption service availability.
In one out of three adoption applicant records reviewed, the agency did not provide
an orientation for the prospective applicant for adoption before the adoptive
application was provided. The adoption application was signed on February 3, 2020
and the adoption orientation was completed on February 12, 2020.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
5

MDHHS Policy Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes.
FOM 722-06B
The following events shall trigger FTM for out of home
cases:
• Case Plan Development/ Reassessment:
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case
Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
• Placement preservation/disruption - At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement or
no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change. Planned and unplanned placement
changes include reunification, placement in a residential
setting, step-down from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
• Semi-Annual Transition Meeting - within 30 calendar days
after the youth’s 14th birthday and every six months
thereafter. For youth entering out-of-home placement at
age 14 or older, the semi-annual transition meeting must be
held within 30 calendar days of the removal date; see this
item for specific meeting requirements.
Documentation.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every
FTM.
6

In three out six foster children records reviewed, a FTM was not completed timely or
the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting report, was not completed.
 For one foster child’s record, FTMs for case service plan development for the
USPs ending on December 16, 2019 and June 2, 2020 were not completed
within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date. The DHS-1105,
Family Team Meeting report, was not completed for the FTM that occurred on
February 20, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, FTMs for case service plan development for the
USPs ending on October 8, 2019 and December 23, 2019 were not
completed within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date. The DHS-
1105, Family Team Meeting report, was not completed for the FTM that
occurred on May 9, 2019. The foster child turned fourteen years old on June
26, 2019. The semi-annual transition meeting was due by December 23, 2019
and it was completed on July 1, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, a FTM for case service plan development for the
USP ending on July 25, 2019 was not completed within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED for—2018 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 10, 2018.
MDHHS Policy Initial Service Plan: Supervisory Approval.
FOM 722-08
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days
of the report date.
In two out six foster children records reviewed the ISP was not reviewed and
approved within fourteen calendar days of the report date.
 For one foster child’s record, the ISP was completed May 30, 2019 and it was
approved on June 24, 2019.
 For one foster child’s record, the ISP was completed April 8, 2020 and it was
approved on May 27, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 11, 2019.
MDHHS Policy Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan and Service
FOM 722-08C Agreement (Signatures).
For both ISP and USP, the PATP must be signed by the worker,
supervisor, parent(s), foster parents/caregivers, and children 14
years and older. If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the PATP, foster care workers must identify and document
additional action needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
7

participation in service planning and compliance with the PATP.
As the goals are achieved, modified or expanded, the updated
PATP will reflect this process. Parents and youths age 14 and
older must participate in the development of each updated
treatment plan, allowing for opportunity to evaluate their
progress towards completing goals.
In three out of six foster children records reviewed, the PATPs did not contain all of
the required signatures.
 For one foster child’s record, the PATP with report period end date February
1, 2020 was not signed by the parent.
 For one foster child’s record, the PATP with report period end date May 25,
2019 was not signed by the parent and caregiver. The PATP with report
period end date July 21, 2019 was not signed by the parent. The PATP with
report period end date March 22, 2020 was not signed by the parent.
 For one foster child’s record, the PATP with report period end date June 9,
2019 was not signed by the parent.
DHHS Policy Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval.
FOM 722-09
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
In five out of six foster children records reviewed, all of the USPs were not reviewed
and approved within fourteen calendar days of the report date.
 For one foster child’s record, the USP was completed on December 16, 2019
and it was approved on January 7, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, one USP was completed on July 25, 2019 and it
was approved on August 21, 2019. One USP was completed on October 8,
2019 and it was approved October 28, 2019. One USP was completed
December 23, 2019 and it was approved on January 27, 2020. One USP was
completed on March 22, 2020 and it was approved on April 21, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2018 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 10, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 11, 2019.
MDHHS Policy Medical Passports.
FOM 801
For children first entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided to the foster care provider
8

within two weeks of the child's placement date. The actual
date the foster care provider receives the medical passport
must be documented in MiSACWIS.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another caseworker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought
and obtained the necessary information under law and
MDHHS policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
--Quarterly.
--At reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
--At or prior to each placement.
--Quarterly.
For every placement/replacement the foster care provider
must be provided with the child's current medical passport
at or prior to placing the child.
9

In three out of six foster children records reviewed, the medical passport was not
provided to the child’s foster care provider/parent or signed by the current foster care
worker per the timeframes specified in the policy.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not signed quarterly
by the foster parent. The foster child was placed in the home on December
21, 2017. There is one medical passport with no date next to the foster
parent’s signature (the foster care worker signed on February 19, 2018).The
foster parent signed the medical passport on July 16, 2018, November 14,
2018, February 20, 2019, June 24, 2019, October 21,2019 and April 9, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not signed by the
relative within two weeks of the foster child's placement date and quarterly
thereafter. The foster child was placed with the relative on April 26, 2019. The
relative signed the medical passport on September 30, 2019, December 16,
2019, January 29, 2020 and July 1, 2020.
 For one foster child’s record, the medical passport was not signed at or prior
to placement and quarterly thereafter. The foster child was replaced in her
current placement on May 23, 2019. The relative signed the medical passport
on June 17, 2019, December 10, 2019, April 28, 2020 and July 14, 2020.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2018 Interim Inspection, CAP approved
September 10, 2018.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED—2019 Renewal Inspection, CAP approved
June 11, 2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was not offered technical assistance.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
There were two incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency received a complaint on January 24, 2019. The allegation was that the
foster child attends visits with marks and bruises and recently had bruises on his
head. It is alleged that the foster child sustained the injuries in the foster home. The
foster home was found to be in non-compliance of R 400.9404 (3) Behavior
management. The agency’s behavior management policy states the agency will not
tolerate the use of the following methods of discipline: 1. Any form of corporal
10

punishment, physical discipline, and any kind of punishment inflicted on the body.
This includes spanking, slapping, hitting or the use of a switch, belt, paddle,
extension cord or other object to strike a child and tapping, or slapping a child on the
hand, head, arm, leg, etc. The discipline policy that applies to foster children in the
home also applies to biological, adopted or guardian children in the home, in order to
show equity of discipline. The foster parent reported she uses physical discipline on
her adopted children. The agency recommended no change in the regular status of
the foster home’s license upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan. The
corrective action plan for the foster parent included that the foster parent agreed to
refrain from using physical discipline on any children in her home. The foster parent
reviewed and signed the agency’s behavior management policy. The agency’s
handling of this special evaluation was appropriate.
The agency received a complaint on February 17, 2020. The allegation was that the
foster father would sometimes spank the foster child with his hand and sometimes
would use a book to hit him. The foster home was found to be in non-compliance of
R 400.9404 (3) Behavior management. The agency’s behavior management policy
states the agency will not tolerate the use of the following methods of discipline: 1.
Any form of corporal punishment, physical discipline, and any kind of punishment
inflicted on the body. This includes spanking, slapping, hitting or the use of a switch,
belt, paddle, extension cord or other object to strike a child and tapping, or slapping
a child on the hand, head, arm, leg, etc. The discipline policy that applies to foster
children in the home also applies to biological, adopted or guardian children in the
home, in order to show equity of discipline. The foster parents’ biological child
reported she is spanked as a form of discipline. The agency recommended no
change in the regular status of the foster home’s license upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan. The corrective action plan for the foster parent
included the foster parents completing the behavior management positive discipline
training. The agency’s handling of this special evaluation was appropriate.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a CAP on September 7, 2018 for the Interim Inspection
that was completed in July 2018. The CAP was approved on September 10,
2018. The agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the
agency received the following repeat violations during the current Interim
Inspection:
 R 400.12212 (2)(f) Personnel records
 R 400.12418 (2)(b) Development of service plans
 MDHHS Policy FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings: Types and Timeframes
 MDHHS Policy FOM 722-09 Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval
 MDHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
The agency submitted a CAP on July 11, 2019 for the Renewal Inspection that
was completed in May 2019. The CAP was approved on July 11, 2019. The
11

agency is in non-compliance with sections of the CAP, as the agency received
the following repeat violations during the current Interim Inspection:
 R 400.12418 (2)(a) and (b) Development of service plans
 MDHHS Policy FOM 722-08 Initial Service Plan: Supervisory Approval
 MDHHS Policy FOM 722-09 Updated Service Plan: Supervisory Approval
 MDHHS Policy FOM 801 Medical Passports
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend that the facility continue on a regular
license.
August 13, 2020
________________________________________
Alicia Wiggins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 14, 2020
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
Area Manager
